raw_text: There is work on lexicon induction using string distance or other phonetic/orthographic comparison techniques, such as Mann and Yarowsky (2001) or semantic comparison using resources such as WordNet (Kondrak, 2001)
clean_text: There is work on lexicon induction using string distance or other phonetic/orthographic comparison techniques, such as Mann and Yarowsky (2001).

raw_text: Moreover, while some techniques (e.g., Mann and Yarowsky (2001)) use multiple languages, the languages used have resources such as dictionaries between some language pairs
clean_text: Moreover, while some techniques (e.g., Mann and Yarowsky (2001)) use multiple languages, the languages used have resources such as dictionaries between some language pairs.

citing_paper_authors: Jirka, Hana | Anna, Feldman | Luiz, Amaral | Chris, Brew
raw_text: Mann and Yarowsky (2001) present a method for inducing translation lexicons based on trasduction modules of cognate pairs via bridge languages. Bilingual lexicons within language families are induced using probabilistic string edit distance models
clean_text: Mann and Yarowsky (2001) present a method for inducing translation lexicons based on trasduction modules of cognate pairs via bridge languages.

citing_paper_authors: Jirka, Hana | Anna, Feldman | Luiz, Amaral | Chris, Brew
raw_text: Similarly to Mann and Yarowsky (2001), we show that languages are often close enough to others within their language family so that cognate pairs between the two are common, and significant portions of the translation lexicon can be induced with high accuracy where no bilingual dictionary or parallel corpora may exist
clean_text: Similarly to Mann and Yarowsky (2001), we show that languages are often close enough to others within their language family so that cognate pairs between the two are common, and significant portions of the translation lexicon can be induced with high accuracy where no bilingual dictionary or parallel corpora may exist.

raw_text: Mann and Yarowsky (2001) applied the stochastic transducer of Ristad and Yianilos (1998) for inducing translation lexicons between two languages, but found that in some cases it offered no improvement over Levenshtein distance
clean_text: Mann and Yarowsky (2001) applied the stochastic transducer of Ristad and Yianilos (1998) for inducing translation lexicons between two languages, but found that in some cases it offered no improvement over Levenshtein distance.

raw_text: LLW stands for Levenshtein with learned weights, which is a modification of R& amp; Y proposed by Mann and Yarowsky (2001)
clean_text: LLW stands for Levenshtein with learned weights, which is a modification of RY proposed by Mann and Yarowsky (2001).

raw_text: As mentioned in (Mann and Yarowsky, 2001), it appears that there are significant differences between the pronunciation task and the cognate iden 49tification task
clean_text: As mentioned in (Mann and Yarowsky, 2001), it appears that there are significant differences between the pronunciation task and the cognate identification task.

raw_text: Mann and Yarowsky (2001) saw little improvement over Edit Distance when applying this transducer to cognates, even when filtering the transducer? s probabilities into different weight classes to better approximate Edit Distance
clean_text: Mann and Yarowsky (2001) saw little improvement over Edit Distance when applying this transducer to cognates, even when filtering the transducer's probabilities into different weight classes to better approximate Edit Distance.

raw_text: For ex ample, Mann and Yarowsky (2001) define a word pair (e, f) to be cognate if they are a translation pair (same meaning) and their Edit Distance is less than three (same form)
clean_text: For example, Mann and Yarowsky (2001) define a word pair (e, f) to be cognate if they are a translation pair (same meaning) and their Edit Distance is less than three (same form).

citing_paper_authors: Nikesh, Garera | Chris, Callison-Burch | David, Yarowsky
raw_text: languages that have more resources (Mann and Yarowsky, 2001)
clean_text: The marked difference in the availability of monolingual vs parallel corpora has led several researchers to develop methods for automatically learning bilingual lexicons, either by using monolingual corpora (Rapp, 1999; Koehn and Knight, 2002; Schafer and Yarowsky, 2002; Haghighi et al., 2008) or by exploiting the cross-language evidence of closely related "bridge" languages that have more resources (Mann and Yarowsky, 2001).

raw_text: Mann and Yarowsky (2001) investigated the induction of translation lexicons via bridge languages
clean_text: Mann and Yarowsky (2001) investigated the induction of translation lexicons via bridge languages.

raw_text: Somewhatsurprisingly, the Hidden Markov Model falls well short of the baseline Levenshteindistance.3Mann and Yarowsky (2001) developed yet another model, which outperformed all other similarity measures
clean_text: Mann and Yarowsky (2001) developed yet another model, which outperformed all other similarity measures.

raw_text: However, our initial experiments indicated that this method does not perform well on the word similarity task.3The HMM model of (Mann and Yarowsky, 2001) is of distinctly different design than our PHMM model
clean_text: The HMM model of (Mann and Yarowsky, 2001) is of distinctly different design than our PHMM model.

citing_paper_authors: Mans, Hulden | Iñaki, Alegria | Izaskun, Etxeberria | Montse, Maritxalar
raw_text: Mann and Yarowsky (2001) present a method for inducing translation lexicons based on transduction models of cognate pairs via bridge languages. Bilingual lexicons within languages families are induced using probabilistic string edit distance mod els
clean_text: Mann and Yarowsky (2001) present a method for inducing translation lexicons based on transduction models of cognate pairs via bridge languages.

raw_text: Our work is inspired by Mann and Yarowsky (2001)
clean_text: Our work is inspired by Mann and Yarowsky (2001).

raw_text: Mann and Yarowsky (2001) distinguish between static metrics, which are sufficiently general to be applied to any language pair, and adaptive metrics, which are adapted to a specific language pair
clean_text: Mann and Yarowsky (2001) distinguish between static metrics, which are sufficiently general to be applied to any language pair, and adaptive metrics, which are adapted to a specific language pair.

raw_text: Mann and Yarowsky (2001) use variants of Levenshtein distance as a static metric, and a Hidden Markov Model (HMM) and a stochastic transducer trained with the Expectation-Maximisation (EM) algorithm as adaptive metrics
clean_text: Mann and Yarowsky (2001) use variants of Levenshtein distance as a static metric, and a Hidden Markov Model (HMM) and a stochastic transducer trained with the Expectation-Maximisation (EM) algorithm as adaptive metrics.

raw_text: Mann and Yarowsky (2001) consider a word pair as cognate if the Levenshtein distance between the two words is less than 3
clean_text: Mann and Yarowsky (2001) consider a word pair as cognate if the Levenshtein distance between the two words is less than 3.

raw_text: This finding is consistent with the results of Mann and Yarowsky (2001), although our experiments show more clear-cut differences
clean_text: This finding is consistent with the results of Mann and Yarowsky (2001), although our experiments show more clear-cut differences.

raw_text: Using the same models, Mann and Yarowsky (2001) induce dover 90% of the Spanish-Portuguese cognate vocabulary
clean_text: Using the same models, Mann and Yarowsky (2001) induced over 90% of the Spanish-Portuguese cognate vocabulary.
